questions.text: A 48-year-old presents with complaints of progressive dysphagia for 4 months. Upper GI endoscopy revealed areas of erythematous mucosa of 3 cm. The histopathology image of the biopsied lesion is shown below. Which of the following complications is most likely to occur as a consequence of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The biopsy specimen shows squamous epithelium along with columnar metaplasia, typical of Barrett's oesophagus. Patients with a focus of Barrett's oesophagus have a higher risk of developing adenocarcinoma than the general population.

Barrett's oesophagus:

  • Barrett's oesophagus is characterised by intestinal metaplasia within the oesophageal squamous mucosa and is associated with an increased risk of cancer.
  • Metaplasia occurs > 1cm above the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Most common among whites, males and obese individuals.
  • Intestinal columnar epithelium of Barrett's oesophagus is more resistant to acid-pepsin and bile.
  • The patient presents with a long history of heartburn and other reflux symptoms.
  • It's a major risk factor for adenocarcinoma.

Diagnosis: Upper GI endoscopy and biopsy

  • Tongues of red velvety GI mucosa (salmon red appearance) between pale squamous mucosa of the lower oesophagus and pink gastric mucosa.
  • Microscopically, intestinal-type metaplasia is seen as replacement of the squamous oesophageal epithelium with goblet cells.
  • Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett's oesophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain pale blue and impart the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.

Fig: Barrett's oesophagus A) Normal gastroesophageal junction (B) Barrett's oesophagus.

Treatment:

  • Anti-reflux therapy
  • Endoscopy every 1-2 years to detect dysplasia or early adenocarcinoma.

Explanation of other options:

Achalasia (Option A): Refers to the failure of the lower oesophageal sphincter to relax, which gives rise to dilation of the proximal portion of the oesophagus. Barium swallow shows, bird-beak appearance.

Lymphoma (Option C): Lymphomas of the oesophagus are very rare and can present with dysphagia. It will show diffuse infiltration of atypical lymphocytes in the lamina propria.

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option D): Squamous cell carcinomas occur in the mid-oesophagus, but they do not arise in association with Barrett's oesophagus. Instead, they are linked to smoking and alcohol consumption.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman presents with dysphagia and weight loss over the past few months. Barium swallow and other radiological investigations revealed irregular narrowing of the lower third of the oesophagus. A biopsy was taken, and given below is the histopathological image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histopathological image shows markedly atypical cuboidal cells lining irregular-shaped gland-like structures, suggestive of adenocarcinoma oesophagus.

Oesophageal adenocarcinoma

  • Oesophageal adenocarcinoma typically arises in the background of Barrett's oesophagus and long-standing GERD.

Pathogenesis: Genetic mutation in adenocarcinoma

  • Morphologic features:
    • Gross: Circumferential papillary lesion or ulcerative polypodal lesion
    • Microscopy: Atypical glands infiltrating the stroma.
  • Endoscopic surveillance for adenocarcinoma is now commonly done in patients with Barrett's oesophagus, particularly those with dysplasia.
  • Tumours tend to grow into the lumen of the oesophagus.
  • The affected region of the oesophagus is typically indurated and ulcerated, causing pain and bleeding.

Fig: Gross specimen of oesophageal adenocarcinoma

Explanation of other options:

Oesophageal stricture (Option B): Oesophageal strictures are generally caused by fibrous thickening of the submucosa and are associated with atrophy of the muscularis propria and secondary epithelial damage. Most often, it occurs due to inflammation and scarring that may be caused by chronic gastroesophageal reflux, irradiation, or caustic injury.

Leiomyosarcoma (Option C): These are malignant tumours arising from smooth muscles. Histopathology shows spindle-shaped cells with atypia and sometimes infiltration of the lamina propria. They lack glandular structures, which are classically seen in adenocarcinoma.

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option D): In SCC, HPE will show malignant squamous cells with occasional keratin Pearl formation, and patients present with dysphagia.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient presents with complaints of progressive dysphagia for 6 months. Endoscopy revealed a polypoidal mass protruding into the lumen in the middle third of the oesophagus. Punch biopsy from the mass was taken, and the histopathological image is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histopathology image shows keratin formation and epithelial pearls, which, when correlated with symptoms of progressive dysphagia and a polypoidal mass in the middle third of the oesophagus, indicate squamous cell carcinoma of the oesophagus.

Squamous cell carcinoma of the oesophagus

SCC of the oesophagus typically occurs in the middle third of the oesophagus, unlike adenocarcinoma, which occurs in the distal third.

  • Risk factors
    • Alcohol, smoking
    • Hot beverages
    • Celiac diseases, Crohn's disease
    • Chronic achalasia
    • Drugs, radiation, deficiency of vitamin A, and zinc
    • Extodermal dysplasia
    • Epidermolysis bullosa
    • HPV infection
    • Plummer-Vinson syndrome
  • Clinical features
    • Patients typically have dysphagia, odynophagia (pain on swallowing) and obstruction.
    • Weight loss and debilitation result from both impaired nutrition and tumour cachexia.
  • Morphological features
    • Gross: Ulcerative lesions present with dysphagia; Exophytic lesions present with symptoms of obstruction.
    • Microscopy: Keratin pearls indicate well-differentiated SCC and have a squamoid appearance.

Explanation of other options:

Adenocarcinoma (Option A): Adenocarcinoma shows glands lined by atypical (malignant) cells with infiltration in the lamina propria.

Leiomyoma (Option C): These are the most common benign oesophageal tumours originating in smooth muscles. 90% of leiomyomas are located in the lower two-thirds of the oesophagus. Microscopy shows benign interlacing spindle-shaped cells with cigar-shaped nuclei arranged in a whirl.

Leiomyosarcoma (Option D): Leiomyosarcomas are uncommon malignant tumours arising from smooth muscles. Histologically, they consist of eosinophilic spindle cells with blunt-ended, hyperchromatic nuclei arranged in interweaving fascicles.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the ER in acute distress with vague chest pain and difficulty swallowing. He refuses to drink water and drools excessively. Vital signs are stable. The mother reports witnessing him ingesting a liquid used to clear drains. If this chemical were a strong acid, which of the following histopathologic findings would be expected in the oesophagus of this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ingestion of strong acids produces an immediate coagulative necrosis in the oesophagus, which results in a protective eschar that limits injury and further chemical penetration.

  • The stratified squamous mucosa of the oesophagus may be damaged by a variety of irritants, including alcohol, corrosive acids or alkalis, excessively hot fluids, and heavy smoking.
  • Symptoms range from self-limited pain, particularly on swallowing, called odynophagia, to haemorrhage, stricture, or perforation in severe cases.
  • Mucosal surfaces following burns from corrosives like acid undergo protein denaturation and coagulative necrosis.

Explanation of other options:

Apoptosis (Option A): Refers to programmed cell death is a central feature of normal tissue development and turnover and can be triggered by extrinsic signals, including cytotoxic T cells or inflammatory cytokines or intrinsic pathways, including DNA damage or intracellular stress. Apoptosis does not result from acid or alkali injury.

Hyaline sclerosis (Option C): Refers to the accumulation of homogeneous, glassy, eosinophilic material in tissues. Seen in long-standing hypertension and diabetes mellitus. The walls of arterioles, especially in the kidney, become hyalinized, resulting from extravasated plasma protein and deposition of basement membrane material.

Liquefactive necrosis (Option D): Ingestion of strong alkaline solutions is accompanied by liquefactive necrosis, with inflammation and saponification of membrane lipids. Alkaline solutions are generally odourless and tasteless and, therefore, easily swallowed before protective reflexes come into play.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis complains of weakness and fatigue. She states that her stools have recently become black after taking a new nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug. Gastroscopy shows numerous superficial, bleeding mucosal defects. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical findings and history typically suggest NSAID-induced acute erosive gastritis.

  • Chronic use of NSAIDs like aspirin can result in acute erosive gastritis, which may produce gastrointestinal bleeding and lead to gastric ulceration.
  • A bleeding tendency may appear concurrently with chronic toxicity because aspirin acetylates the platelet cyclooxygenase and irreversibly blocks the production of thromboxane A2, an activator of platelet aggregation.
  • Petechial haemorrhages may appear in the skin and internal organs, and bleeding from gastric ulcerations may be exacerbated by the clotting defect.
  • There is a breakdown of the mucosal barrier, which permits acid-induced injury. Mucosal injury causes bleeding from superficial erosions. Defects in the mucosa may extend into the deeper tissues to form an ulcer.
  • The necrosis is accompanied by an acute inflammatory response and haemorrhage, which may be severe enough to result in exsanguination and hypovolemic shock.
  • Acute hemorrhagic gastritis is characterised by necrosis of the mucosa and is commonly associated with the intake of aspirin, other NSAIDs, alcohol, or ischemic injury.

Explanation of other options:

Early gastric cancer (Option A): Early gastric carcinoma is limited to the mucosa and submucosa and presents with dyspepsia and weight loss. Grossly, lesions may be polypoid, superficial or ulcerated.

Helicobacter pylori gastritis (Option C): H. pylori infection most often presents as a predominantly antral gastritis with normal or increased acid production. Patients have an increased risk of gastric or duodenal peptic ulcer disease.

Duodenal ulcer(Option D): Duodenal ulcers are commonly associated with NSAID use and H.pylori infections. Presents with pain relief following food intake, and endoscopy will show discrete ulcers.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 4-month history of burning epigastric pain that usually occurs between meals and is relieved with antacids or food. The patient also reports dark, tarry stools. She denies using aspirin or NSAIDs. Gastroscopy reveals a bleeding mucosal defect in the antrum measuring 1.5 cm in diameter. An endoscopic biopsy taken from the antrum is shown below. Based on the clinical findings and histopathological image features, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The described presentation is suggestive of peptic ulcer disease with possible ulceration. The antral location of the ulcer, along with a history of not using NSAIDs and HPE finding of neutrophilic infiltration of the lamina propria, suggests Helicobacter pylori gastritis.

  • H.pyolori causes:
    • Pan gastritis
    • Type Gastritis
    • Adenocarcinoma and MALT lymphoma of the stomach

Helicobacter pylori gastritis:

  • H.pylori results in type B Gastritis. These are chronic gastritis, with the most common site being the gastric antrum.
  • Characterised by prominent chronic inflammation of the antrum and body of the stomach, patients will have associated peptic ulcers.

Diagnosis of H. pylori infection:

  • Biopsy is the gold standard test.
  • Special stains used:
    • Silver stains like Steiner (preferred) and Warthin starry stains
    • Giemsa/acridine orange
  • Rapid urease test on gastric mucosal biopsy is a 100% specific test.
  • Histopathology:
    • Shows an inflammatory infiltrate that includes large numbers of plasma cells, often in clusters or sheets, within the superficial lamina propria.
    • These are accompanied by increased numbers of lymphocytes, macrophages, and neutrophils within the lamina propria.
    • Neutrophils infiltrate across the basement membrane and accumulate in the lumens of gastric glands, or pits, to create pit abscesses.

Fig: Spiral-shaped H. pylori in Warthin-Starry silver stain

Explanation of other options:

Achlorhydria (Option A), Autoimmunity (Option C): Achlorhydria is seen in autoimmune gastritis (Type A gastritis) and is due to circulating antibodies against parietal cells and intrinsic factor. Also sometimes seen in autoimmune diseases like Hashimoto's thyroiditis and Addison's disease. In patients with achlorhydria, peptic ulcers are less likely.

Acute ischemia (Option B): Acute ischemia will present acutely, and patients will have acute abdominal pain due to necrosis of the bowel.

questions.text: A 59-year-old female consulted her physician after noticing swellings in her neck. Physical examination showed enlarged and nontender supraclavicular lymph nodes. Upper GI endoscopy showed thickening of the gastric mucosa, without an obvious tumour. The results of the gastric biopsy are shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histopathology image shows the neoplastic lymphocytes infiltrating the gastric glands to create diagnostic lymphoepithelial lesions. Painless neck swelling and enlarged, non-tender cervical lymph nodes, and the HPE image suggests gastric lymphoma.

Gastric lymphoma:

  • Gastric lymphoma is the most common form of extranodal lymphoma, accounting for 20% of all such tumours.
  • The stomach is the most common site for lymphoma in the GIT, and the most common site in the stomach is the antrum.
  • The most common gastric lymphoma is diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) > MALToma > follicular lymphoma.
  • DLBCL is the most common type of non-Hodgkin extra-nodal lymphoma and GI lymphoma.
  • MALT lymphoma:
    • Most common site - stomach.
    • Seen in older patients 6th to 7th decades.
    • Vague symptoms like epigastric pain, anaemia
    • Histologically, gastric MALToma takes the form of a dense lymphocytic infiltrate in the lamina propria.

Explanation of other options:

GIST (Option A): Gastric GISTs are usually submucosal and covered by intact mucosa.

Microscopically, the tumours show spindle cells with vacuolated cytoplasm.

Leiomyosarcoma (Option C): Leiomyosarcomas are uncommon malignant tumours arising from smooth muscles. Histologically, they consist of eosinophilic spindle cells with blunt-ended, hyperchromatic nuclei arranged in interweaving fascicles.

Menetrier's disease (Option D): Menetrier's disease is a rare disorder associated with excessive secretion of transforming growth factor (TGF)-α and hyperactivation of the epidermal growth factor receptor on gastric epithelial cells. Some cases occur in association with viral or H. pylori infection. Characterised by diffuse hyperplasia of foveolar epithelium within the body and fundus, as well as hypoproteinemia due to albumin loss. Secondary symptoms such as weight loss, diarrhoea, and peripheral oedema are commonly present.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman complains of abdominal pain and dark, tarry stools. Upper GI endoscopy revealed a firm, smooth, yellowish submucosal ulcerated mass in the stomach. Gastroscopic biopsy reveals spindle cells with vacuolated cytoplasm. The mass is removed, and the histopathology of the surgical specimen is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gross morphology of the specimen described above, along with HPE, showing spindle cells with vacuolated cytoplasm, suggests a gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST) in women.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumour:

  • The most common mesenchymal tumour of the GI tract.
  • The most common primary site for GIST is the stomach.
  • GISTs are derived from the pacemaker cells of Cajal.
  • They include the vast majority of mesenchymederived stromal tumours of the entire gastrointestinal tract.
  • Associated mutations:
    • KIT > PDGFRA > Wild-type GIST.
    • Most common mutation - receptor Tyrosine kinase KIT (CD 117)
  • Gastric GISTs are usually submucosal and covered by intact mucosa.
  • Microscopically, the tumours show spindle cells with vacuolated cytoplasm.
  • GISTs are considered to be of low malignant potential and are removed surgically.

Fig: GIST A) Histology showing spindle cells, b) Gross specimen

Explanation of other options:

Gastric adenocarcinoma (Option A): Gastric adenocarcinomas are classified according to their location and gross and histologic morphology. Most distal gastric adenocarcinomas occur in the gastric antrum; the lesser curvature is involved more often than the greater curvature. Gastric tumours with an intestinal morphology form bulky tumours and are composed of glandular structures, while cancers with a diffuse infiltrative growth pattern are typically composed of signet-ring cells.

Gastric lymphoma (Option B): Gastric lymphoma is the most common form of extranodal lymphoma, accounting for 20% of all such tumours. Histologically, gastric MALToma takes the form of a dense lymphocytic infiltrate in the lamina propria. The neoplastic lymphocytes infiltrate gastric glands to create diagnostic lymphoepithelial lesions.

Tubular adenoma (Option D): Tubular adenomas tend to be small, pedunculated polyps composed of rounded or tubular glands. Histologically characterised by nuclear enlargement, elongation, pseudostratification, and hyperchromasia. High-grade dysplasia is marked by glandular budding and gland-within-gland, or cribriform structures.

questions.text: A 59-year-old male presented with symptoms of sweating, colicky abdominal pain, diarrhoea and occasional bronchospasm for 3 months. Upper GI endoscopy showed a small lesion in the submucosa, causing a mild polypoid protrusion in the lumen of the stomach. A punch biopsy was taken, the histopathological image of which is shown below. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

HPE shows a salt and pepper chromatin appearance typical of neuroendocrine tumours, which, along with the presence of a submucosal polyp, suggests the likely diagnosis to be a carcinoid tumour.

Carcinoid tumours:

  • Carcinoid tumours are well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumours.
  • Most are found in the GI tract, and more than 40% occur in the small intestine. The tracheobronchial tree and lungs are the next most commonly involved sites.
  • Gastric neuroendocrine neoplasms may be associated with endocrine cell hyperplasia, autoimmune chronic atrophic gastritis, MEN1, and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.

Gross features:

  • Neuroendocrine neoplasms are intramural or submucosal masses that create polypoid lesions.
  • Neuroendocrine neoplasms tend to be yellow or tan and are very firm as a consequence of intense desmoplasia, which may cause kinking and obstruction of the small bowel.

Microscopic fetaures:

  • Well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumours are composed of islands, trabeculae, strands, and sheets of uniform cells with scant, pink granular cytoplasm and a round to oval nucleus with a "salt and pepper" chromatin pattern.

Fig: Neuroendocrine tumour (carcinoid tumour). (A) Gross cross-section of a submucosal tumour nodule. (B) Microscopy showing "salt and pepper" pattern.

Explanation of other options:

Adenocarcinoma (Option A): Histopathological image shows gastric glands lined by atypical malignant epithelial cells suggestive of adenocarcinoma. Gastric adenocarcinomas are classified according to their location and gross and histologic morphology. Most distal gastric adenocarcinomas occur in the gastric antrum; the lesser curvature is involved more often than the greater curvature.

Lymphoma (Option B): Gastric lymphoma is the most common form of extranodal lymphoma, accounting for 20% of all such tumours. Histologically, gastric MALToma takes the form of a dense lymphocytic infiltrate in the lamina propria. The neoplastic lymphocytes infiltrate gastric glands to create diagnostic lymphoepithelial lesions.

GIST (Option C): Gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST) is the most common mesenchymal tumour of the abdomen. They usually form a solitary, well-circumscribed, fleshy mass. The overlying mucosa is frequently ulcerated, and the cut tumour surface has a whorled appearance. Histology shows proliferation of spindle cells with vaculated cytoplasm.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with nausea, chronic diarrhoea, along with bloating and fatigue for 2 years. On examination, he is anaemic, and upper GI endoscopy revealed a scalloped border in the D2 region. A biopsy was taken from the same region, and an image of which is shown below. Which of the following histopathological findings will be taken into consideration for the interpretation of this duodenal biopsy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

From the endoscopic findings and clinical picture, the patient is suffering from celiac disease.

The histopathological image clearly shows villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia, characteristic of celiac disease.

Celiac disease

  • Celiac disease, also known as celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy, is an immune-mediated disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten-containing foods such as wheat, rye, or barley.
  • The alcohol-soluble fraction of gluten, gliadin, contains most of the disease-producing components.

Clinical features

  • More common in children
  • Presents with symptoms of malabsorption - diarrhoea, weight loss, abdominal distension

Serological test

  • Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (IgA): Most sensitive test for celiac disease.
  • In patients with IgA deficiency, test for IgG anti-deamidated gliadin peptides (DGP) instead.
  • Anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA): Most specific test.

Histopathology

  • The site of biopsy in Celiac disease is the 2nd part of the duodenum
  • Features:
    • Villous atrophy
    • Crypt hyperplasia
    • Intraepithelial lymphocytes (CD8 >> CD4)

Fig: Histology of Celiac disease showing. (A) Complete loss of villi, or total villous atrophy. B) Infiltration of the surface epithelium by T lymphocytes

Complications

  • Dermatitis herpetiformis
  • Individuals with celiac disease have an increased risk of malignancy.
    • The most common cancer is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma, an aggressive lymphoma of intraepithelial T lymphocytes.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with fever and painful joints for 2 weeks. On examination, he has skin pigmentation, glossitis, angular cheilitis, and generalised lymphadenopathy. The patient has lost 9 kg over the past 6 months. He reports pale and foul-smelling stools. Blood cultures are negative. He was started on antibiotic therapy and showed a remarkable clinical improvement. A biopsy of the small intestine is taken, and the histopathological image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Biopsy of the small intestine given above shows marked distortion of the intestinal villi and numerous foamy macrophages, suggestive of Whipple disease.

Whipple disease

  • It's a rare infectious disorder of the small intestine in which malabsorption is the most prominent feature.
  • Caused by Tropheryma whipplei, a Gram-positive actinomycete.
  • Typically features infiltration of the small bowel mucosa by macrophages that are packed with small, rod-shaped bacilli (Tropheryma whipplei).

Clinical manifestations

Acute infection

  • Acute gastroenteritis, pneumonia

Chronic infection

  • The most common joint involvement is arthritis; it worsens with steroids, but improves with antibiotics.
  • CNS
    • Dementia is the most common manifestation
    • The most specific manifestation is conergent/divergent nystagmus with masticatory jaw muscle involvement. This is called the oculo-masticatory myorhythmia.
    • Encephalopathy
    • Supranuclear ophthalmoplegia
  • CVS: The most common feature is pericarditis
  • Eye: The most common feature is uveitis

Diagnosis

  • Histopathology:
    • Foamy macrophages
    • PAS-positive macrophage in the lamina propria
    • Gram positive
    • Acid-fast negative
  • PCR: Whipple disease is a benign disease showing metastasis, i.e presents like a malignant disease.

Fig: Whipple disease A) Hematoxylin and eosin staining shows lamina propria with distended macrophages. B) PAS stains with macrophage lysosomes full of bacilli.

Explanation of other options:

Celiac disease (Option A): It's a gluten-induced enteropathy due to gluten intolerance. More common in children, they present with malabsorption symptoms like diarrhoea, weight loss, and abdominal distension; they show no systemic involvement. HPE shows villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and intraepithelial lymphocytes.

Tropical sprue (Option B): Also known as environmental enteropathy, the most common endemic organism implicated is E.coli. Symptoms of malabsorption, though present, are not accompanied by any systemic features. Histopathology shows villi atrophy, crypt enlargement, and intraepithelial lymphocytes.

Crohn's disease (Option C): In most patients, the disease begins with intermittent attacks of relatively mild diarrhoea, fever, and abdominal pain. Extraintestinal manifestations of Crohn's disease include uveitis, migratory polyarthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, and erythema nodosum. The microscopical findings include abundant neutrophils that infiltrate and damage the crypt epithelium, and non-caseating granulomas.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents with increasingly severe diarrhoea that began 1 week after returning from a trip to Central America. Gross examination of the stools showed mucus and streaks of blood. Colposcopy showed an ulcer in the sigmoid colon, and a biopsy from that ulcerated area was taken. The histopathological image of the biopsy is shown below. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Symptoms of bloody diarrhoea and HPE findings of trophozoites of amoeba showing erythrophagocytosis confirm the diagnosis of amoebic colitis caused by Entamoeba hystolitica.

  • Diarrhoea with mucus and blood in the stools may be caused by several enteroinvasive microorganisms, including Shigella dysenteriae and Entamoeba histolytica.
  • Amoebiasis affects the cecum and ascending colon most often, but the sigmoid colon, rectum, and appendix can also be involved.
  • Dysentery develops when the amoebae attach to the colonic epithelium, induce apoptosis, invade crypts, and burrow laterally into the lamina propria.
  • This recruits neutrophils, causes tissue damage, and creates a flask-shaped ulcer with a narrow neck and broad base.

Explanation of other options:

Cryptosporidium parvum (Option A): Cryptosporidium causes diarrhoea in acquired immunodeficiency syndrome patients. Mucosal histology shows villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and inflammatory infiltrates. Although the sporozoite is intracellular, in light microscopy, it appears to sit on top of the epithelial apical membrane.

Giardia lamblia (Option B): Giardia produces a self-limited, watery diarrhoea. Giardia trophozoites can be identified in duodenal biopsies based on their characteristic pear shape and the presence of two equally sized nuclei.

Strongyloides stercoralis (Option D): In immunocompetent hosts, S. stercoralis is often asymptomatic, but may cause diarrhoea, bloating, and occasionally malabsorption. Immunocompromised hosts can have very high worm burdens due to uncontrolled autoinfection, leading to fatal disease. Histology shows an eosinophil-rich infiltrate in the lamina propria with mucosal oedema.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to a surgeon with complaints of intermittent rectal bleeding for 3 months. On colonoscopy, a small polyp, measuring 1.5 cm in maximum dimension, was identified. Polypectomy was done and sent for histopathological examination, the image of which is shown below. Based on the above findings, the probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histopathology image given above shows cystically dilated glands, which are typically seen in juvenile polyps. The history of rectal bleeding supports the diagnosis.

Juvenile polyps:

  • These are hamartomatous polyps commonly seen in children under 5 years.
  • Involves focal malformations of the epithelium and lamina propria that may be sporadic or syndromic.
  • The most common mutation identified is of SMAD4, which encodes a signalling intermediate in the TGF-β pathway.
  • Pulmonary arteriovenous malformation is an extraintestinal manifestation of juvenile polyposis.
  • Most juvenile polyps are less than 3 cm in diameter. They are typically pedunculated, smooth-surfaced, reddish lesions with characteristic cystic spaces.
  • Microscopic examination shows these cysts to be dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris.

Explanation of other options:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (Option B): This rare autosomal dominant syndrome presents at a median age of 11 years with multiple GI hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation. Grossly, the polyps are large and pedunculated with a lobulated contour. Histologic examination demonstrates a characteristic arborising network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium.

Tubular adenoma (Option C): Tubular adenomas are epithelial neoplasms that tend to be small, pedunculated polyps composed of rounded or tubular glands.  Microscopically, tubular adenomas exhibit closely packed epithelial tubules, which may be uniform or irregular with excessive branching.

Adenocarcinoma  (Option D): Adenocarcinoma of the colon is the most common malignancy of the GI tract and is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Tumours in the proximal colon often grow as polypoid, exophytic masses; in contrast, carcinomas in the distal colon tend to be annular lesions that produce “napkin-ring” constrictions and luminal narrowing. Histology shows glands lined by atypical columnar cells.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl with a familial history of adenocarcinoma in 3 successive generations presents with persistent abdominal discomfort. Colonoscopy and endoscopy revealed multiple polyps in the small intestine and colon. She underwent prophylactic colectomy, and the gross specimen is shown below. Based on the above findings, which gene is likely to be mutated?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above image shows numerous polyps in the excised colectomy segment, which, along with a strong family history of adenocarcinoma, suggests Familial adenomatous polyposis. It is caused by somatic mutations of the APC gene.

Familial adenomatous polyposis:

  • Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant disorder in which patients develop numerous colorectal adenomas as teenagers.
  • At least 100 polyps are necessary for a diagnosis of classic FAP.
  • It is caused by somatic mutations of the adenomatous polyposis coli, or APC, gene, which is a key negative regulator of the Wnt signalling pathway.
  • Approximately 75% of cases are inherited, while the remainder appear to be caused by de novo mutations.

Explanation of other options:

KRAS (Option A): Mutations of the KRAS proto-oncogene are associated with adenocarcinoma of the colon, pancreas, and lungs.

TP 53 (Option B): TP 53 causes cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in response to DNA damage. These are associated with familial syndromes like Li-Fraumeni syndrome.

MLH 1 (Option D): Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer, also known as Lynch syndrome, is associated with at least five mismatch repair genes and mutations in MSH2 or MLH1.

questions.text: During a routine colonoscopy in a 67-year-old woman, a 1 cm mass was identified in the rectosigmoid region and resected. The resected specimen is sent for HPE, and the image of it is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histopathology image of the resected specimen predominantly shows closely packed tubular crypts, suggestive of tubular adenomas.

Colorectal adenomas are characterised by the presence of epithelial dysplasia. Adenomas can be classified as tubular, tubulovillous, or villous based on their architecture.

Tubular adenomas:

  • Tubular adenomas tend to be small, pedunculated polyps composed of rounded or tubular glands.
  • Microscopy shows well-defined tubular glands in the polyp, with < 20% villous component.
  • Dysplasia and carcinoma often develop in tubular adenomas.

Villous adenomas:

  • Villous adenomas are often larger and sessile, and are covered by slender villi.
  • Villous adenomas harbour cancers more frequently than tubular adenomas, but this also correlates with the larger size of villous adenomas.
  • They secrete lots of mucus rich in K+ and present with diarrhoea and hypokalemia.
  • Histology shows villous projections, with > 80% villous component. (Option D ruled out)

Fig: Histopathology of villous adenoma

Tubulovillous adenomas show both tubular and villous components. (Option A ruled out)

Fig: Histopathology of tubulovillous adenoma

Explanation of other options:

Hyperplastic polyps (Option B): Histology of hyperplastic polyps shows mature goblet and absorptive cells with a serrated surface architecture that is the morphologic hallmark of these lesions.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man complains of weakness, easy fatigability and weight loss. He also reports blood-tinged stools. On abdominal examination, there is fullness in the right lower quadrant. Laboratory studies show iron-deficiency anaemia and a positive stool occult blood test. Colonoscopy revealed an elevated and centrally ulcerated lesion of the sigmoid colon. The histopathology image of the biopsy taken is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis is adenocarcinoma of the colon, as suggested by the centrally ulcerated lesion and HPE showing glandular structures lined with malignant cells.

Colorcetal adenocarcinoma:

  • Two genetic pathways associated with colorectal adenocarcinoma:
    • APC/β-catenin pathway
    • MSI pathway.
  • Colorectal cancer invades lymphatic channels and initially involves the lymph nodes immediately underlying the tumour.
  • The two most important prognostic factors are the depth of invasion and the presence of lymph node metastases.

Symptoms of Ca colon:

Explanation of other options:

Carcinoid tumour (Option B): These are well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumours that are composed of islands, trabeculae, strands, glands, and sheets of uniform cells with scant, pink granular cytoplasm and a round to oval nucleus with a “salt and pepper” chromatin pattern.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumour (Option C): Gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST) is the most common mesenchymal tumour of the abdomen. They usually form a solitary, well-circumscribed, fleshy mass. The overlying mucosa is frequently ulcerated, and the cut tumour surface has a whorled appearance. Histology shows proliferation of spindle cells with vaculated cytoplasm.

Mucinous cystadenoma (Option D): Mucinous cystadenomas are primarily seen in the ovary, from where they metastasise to other body sites. They characteristically demonstrate confluent glandular growth, a form of expansile invasion.

choices.text: Distortion and disorganisation of mucosal glands

questions.text: A 42-year-old male with a history of intermittent mild diarrhoea, fever and abdominal pain, now presents with acute abdominal pain and pain in the right lower quadrant. Laboratory findings revealed mild anaemia, hypoproteinemia, and with presence of clubbing. Endoscopy and biopsy were performed. On histopathological examination diagnosis of Crohn's disease was made. Which of the histological features points toward the diagnosis of Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Crypt abscess, distorted and disorganised mucosal gland and Paneth cell metaplasia are important histologic features of Crohn's disease.

  • Crohn's disease is a chronic transmural inflammatory disease.
  • Causes:
    • Saccharomyces cerevisiae
    • Mycobacterium paratuberculosis
    • Measle virus
  • The earliest gross pathologic lesion is a superficial aphthous ulcer.

Microscopic features of Crohn's disease:

  • Crypt abscess: Abundant neutrophils infiltrate and damage the crypt epithelium. These clusters of neutrophils within a crypt are referred to as crypt abscesses and are often associated with the destruction of the crypt.
  • Repeated cycles of crypt destruction and regeneration lead to distortion and disorganisation of mucosal glands; the normally straight and parallel crypts take on bizarre branching shapes and unusual orientations to one another.
  • Paneth cell metaplasia: This may also occur in the left colon, where Paneth cells are normally absent. These architectural and metaplastic changes may persist even when active inflammation has resolved.
  • Noncaseating granulomas, a hallmark of Crohn's disease, are found in approximately 35% of cases and may occur in areas of active disease.

Fig: Microscopic pathology of Crohn's disease. A) Crypt distortion. B) Noncaseating granuloma. C) Transmural Crohn's disease with granulomas (arrows).

questions.text: A 44-year-old male patient presented with recurrent lower abdominal pain and cramps, which are temporarily relieved by defecation. He also reports bloody diarrhoea with mucus. There is a similar history in past. After conservative treatment to relieve symptoms, an endoscopy and biopsy were performed. What will be the gross features most likely seen in endocopy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The symptoms of recurrent abdominal pain relieved with defecation and bloody diarrhoea with mucus are strongly suggestive of ulcerative colitis.

Ulcerative colitis:

  • Inflammation in ulcerative colitis always involves the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous fashion to involve part or all of the colon.
  • Rectal involvement (proctitis) is the hallmark of the disease.

Gross morphological features:

  • Grossly, involved colonic mucosa may be slightly red and granular.
  • There can be an abrupt transition between the diseased and uninvolved colon.
  • Isolated islands of regenerating mucosa often bulge into the lumen to create pseudopolyps.
  • The tips of these polyps may fuse to create mucosal bridges.
  • Broad-based ulcers involving the mucosa and submucosa.
  • Lead-pipe appearance due to loss of haustrations because of continuous ulcer

Fig: Gross pathology of ulcerative colitis. A) Pseudopolyps B) Mucosal bridges

Histological features:

  • Crypt abscess
  • Abnormal branching of crypts
  • Pyloric metaplasia

choices.text: GISTs without mutated KIT or PDGFRA have mutations in the succinate dehydrogenase complex
Mutation of KIT or PDGFRA is an early event in sporadic GISTs
Prognosis correlates with tumour size, mitotic index, and location
Patients having mutations in KIT are imatinib-resistant

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with abdominal pain. Endoscopy showed a mass in the stomach, following which a biopsy was taken. The images are as shown below. Which of the following statements is not true about the case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histopathology image shows proliferation of spindle-shaped cells, and grossly the mass is solitary, well-circumscribed and fleshy, pointing to a likely diagnosis of GIST. GISTs due to mutations in KIT are sensitive to imatinib.

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST) is the most common mesenchymal tumour of the abdomen.
  • Approximately 75% of all GISTs have oncogenic, gain-of-function mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinase KIT.
  • Another 8% of GISTs have mutations that activate the related receptor tyrosine kinase, platelet-derived growth factor receptor α (PDGFRA). (Option A ruled out)
  • GISTs without mutated KIT or PDGFRA often have mutations in genes encoding components of the mitochondrial succinate dehydrogenase complex. (Option A ruled out)
  • Symptoms of GISTs at presentation are typically related to mass effects. Mucosal ulceration can cause blood loss and present with anaemia or related symptoms.
  • Complete surgical resection is the primary treatment for localised gastric GIST.
  • The prognosis correlates with tumour size, mitotic index, and location, with gastric GISTs being less aggressive than those arising in the small intestine. (Option C ruled out)
  • Recurrence or metastasis is rare for gastric GISTs smaller than 5 cm but common for mitotically active tumours larger than 10 cm.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with recurrent bloody diarrhoea. Colonoscopy was done, followed by biopsy; the histopathology image is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Noncaseating granulomas are seen in the histopathology, which is virtually the hallmark of Crohn's disease.

  • Crohn's disease may involve any area of the GI tract and is typically transmural.
  • In most patients, the disease begins with intermittent attacks of relatively mild diarrhoea, fever, and abdominal pain.
  • Approximately 20% of patients present acutely with lower quadrant pain, fever, and bloody diarrhoea that may mimic acute appendicitis or bowel perforation.
  • Periods of active disease are typically interrupted by asymptomatic periods that last for weeks to many months.
  • Disease reactivation can be associated with a variety of external triggers, including physical or emotional stress, specific dietary items, and cigarette smoking.
  • Iron deficiency anaemia due to blood loss may develop in individuals with colonic disease.
  • Extensive small bowel disease may result in protein loss sufficient to cause hypoalbuminemia and malabsorption of nutrients, vitamin B12, and bile salts.
  • Gross features:
    • The earliest gross pathologic lesion is a superficial aphthous ulcer
    • Multiple ulcers coalesce to form a serpentine ulcer
    • Mesenteric fat extends over the serosal surface to cover transmural fat - creeping fat.
    • Cobblestone appearance

Fig: Gross pathology of Crohn's disease. A) Small intestinal stricture. B) Cobblestone appearance. (C) Perforation and associated serositis. (D) Creeping fat.

  • Microscopic features:
    • Crypt abscess
    • Distortion and disorganisation of mucosal glands
    • Paneth cell metaplasia
    • Non-caseating granulomas

Explanation of other options:

Pseudomembranous colitis (Option A): Pseudomembranous colitis is generally caused by Clostridioides difficile and is also referred to as antibiotic-associated colitis. The surface epithelium gets denuded, and the superficial lamina propria contains a dense infiltrate of neutrophils. Histopathology of C. difficile-associated colitis is pathognomonic of the mucopurulent exudate that characteristically erupts from damaged crypts to form “volcano” lesions and coalesces to form pseudomembranes.

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma colon (Option B): Non-Hodgkin lymphoma usually presents with weight loss, abdominal pain and mass. Less commonly present with bloody diarrhoea. Histology shows atypical lymphocytic infiltrations.

Ulcerative colitis (Option C): Grossly, the involved colonic mucosa in ulcerative colitis may be slightly red and granular or have extensive, broad-based ulcers and show pseudopolyps. Histologic features of mucosal disease in ulcerative colitis are crypt abscesses, abnormal branching of crypts and pyloric metaplasia.

choices.text: FAP without mutation in the APC gene have another target of the MYH gene
Prophylactic colectomy prevent the risk of the development of cancer in other organs as well
Gardner syndrome encompasses the subset of FAP patients with a brain tumour.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding colonic polyposis, shown below, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The colonic polyposis syndrome in FAP is Turcot syndrome, which has FAP with brain tumours and not Gardner syndrome.

  • Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant disorder in which patients develop numerous colorectal adenomas as teenagers.
  • It is caused by somatic mutations of the adenomatous polyposis coli, or APC, gene, which is a key negative regulator of the Wnt signalling pathway.
  • At least 100 polyps are necessary for a diagnosis of classic FAP, but thousands may be present.
  • Attenuated FAP is a milder variant of classic Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP), characterised by fewer colonic polyps (40-50).
  • Colorectal adenocarcinoma develops in 100% of untreated FAP patients, often before age 30 and nearly always by age 50. As a result, prophylactic colectomy is the standard of care. (Option B, C ruled out)
  • Colectomy prevents colorectal cancer, but patients remain at risk for neoplasia at other sites.
  • Some polyposis patients without APC loss have bi-allelic mutations of the base-excision repair gene MUTYH (also referred to as MYH). This autosomal recessive disorder is termed MUTYH-associated polyposis, or MAP. (Option A ruled out)
  • In contrast to FAP, MAP is characterised by fewer than 100 polyps, which appear at later ages. Colon cancer development is also delayed.
  • Extraintestinal manifestations of Classic FAP: Congenital RPE hypertrophy

choices.text: Infiltration of histiocytes with RBCs in the lamina propria
Granuloma in the lamina, can be intestinal TB
Macrophages with PAS (+) ve material inside the lamina propria representing Whipple's disease

questions.text: A 30-year-old presented with malabsorption with diarrhoea, weight loss, abdominal pain, occasional polyarthritis, and CNS complaints. Duodenal biopsy shows the following. Which is the correct statement?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Malabsorption with diarrhoea, weight loss, abdominal pain and occasionally polyarthritis, CNS complaints are seen in Whipple's disease. These cases show PAS (+) ve material inside macrophages in the lamina propria layer.

Whipple disease morphology:

  • The morphologic hallmark of Whipple disease is a dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria.
  • The macrophages contain periodic acid Schiff (PAS) positive, diastase-resistant granules that represent partially digested bacteria within lysosomes.
  • Intact rod-shaped bacilli can also be identified by electron microscopy.
  • Villous expansion caused by dense macrophage infiltrates imparts a shaggy gross appearance to the mucosal surface.

Fig: Whipple disease and mycobacterial infection. (A) Hematoxylin and eosin staining (B). Periodic acid–Schiff stain (C) Electron micrograph

Explanation of other options:

Infiltration of histiocytes with RBCs in the lamina propria (Option A): Infiltration of histiocytes with RBCs can be seen in any inflammation and is not typical of Whipple's disease.

Granuloma in the lamina can be intestinal TB (Option B): Patients with intestinal TB present with abdominal pain, weight loss and do not show extra-intestinal symptoms like arthritis or CNS involvement. Histologically, sites of active involvement are marked by a characteristic granulomatous inflammatory reaction that forms both caseating and noncaseating tubercles.

Eosinophils in the lamina propria (Option D): Fully developed celiac disease shows increased numbers of plasma cells, mast cells, and eosinophils, especially within the upper part of the lamina propria. However, hallmark features include intraepithelial lymphocytosis, crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy.

choices.text: Characteristic itchy, blistering skin lesion is seen in 10% cases
Most sensitive tests are the measurement of IgA antibodies against tissue transglutaminase
The most common celiac disease-associated cancer is adenocarcinoma colon
HLA-DQ2 and HLA DQ-8/B8 are useful for their high negative predictive value

questions.text: Intestinal biopsy of a 25-year-old male who presented with symptoms of fatigue, chronic diarrhoea, bloating, and chronic fatigue is given below. What is not true about the given condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The symptoms of fatigue, chronic diarrhoea, bloating, or chronic fatigue are suggestive of malabsorption. Histopathology shows loss of villi and crypt hypertrophy, which indicates celiac disease. Celiac disease causes T cell lymphoma and not adenocarcinoma as the most common tumour.

Celiac disease:

Celiac disease is an autoimmune disease, characterised by gluten-induced enteropathy in gluten-intolerant individuals.

Clinical features:

  • Celiac disease may be associated with chronic diarrhoea, bloating, or chronic fatigue, but can also be asymptomatic.
  • These cases may present with anaemia due to chronic iron and vitamin malabsorption.
  • In adults, celiac disease is detected twice as frequently in women, perhaps because menstrual bleeding accentuates the effects of impaired iron absorption.
  • A characteristic, itchy, blistering skin lesion, dermatitis herpetiformis, can be present in as many as 10% of patients. (Option A ruled out)

Serologic tests in celiac disease:

  • The most sensitive test is the measurement of IgA antibodies against tissue transglutaminase. (Option B ruled out)
  • IgA antiendomysial antibodies can also be present.
  • IgG anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies may be detected in patients with IgA deficiency.
  • The absence of HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 is useful for its negative predictive value, but the presence of these alleles does not help confirm the diagnosis. (Option D ruled out).

Histopathology

  • The site of biopsy in Celiac disease is the 2nd part of the duodenum
  • Features:
    • Villous atrophy
    • Crypt hyperplasia
    • Intraepithelial lymphocytes (CD8 >> CD4)

Risk of malignancy:

  • Individuals with celiac disease have an increased risk of malignancy.
  • The most common cancer is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma, an aggressive lymphoma of intraepithelial T lymphocytes.
  • Small intestinal adenocarcinoma is also more frequent in individuals with celiac disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV positive male presents with complaints of dysphagia. Upper GI endoscopy was done, which showed lesions in the oesophagus, and a biopsy was taken. Endoscopy and histological findings are shown below. Which is the most likely organism suspected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Endoscopy shows a shallow ulcer at the lower end of the oesophagus, while histopathology shows large eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions and multiple small cytoplasmic inclusions. These are suggestive of CMV oesophagitis.

CMV oesophagitis:

  • Cytomegalovirus causes infectious oesophagitis, characterised by shallow linear ulcers.
  • Histology findings
    • Dark basophilic owl-like inclusions, in the nucleus with a perinuclear halo.
    • Coarse inclusions in the cytoplasm are seen at the base of an ulcer in endothelial or stromal cells.

Explanation of other options:

Herpes (Option A): Herpes also causes infective esophagitis, but results in punched-out ulcers/volcano ulcers. Histology findings include multinucleation, margination of chromatin and moulding.

Candida (Option C): Candidal esophagitis is commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals. They show characteristic pseudomembrane formation. Spores and pseudohyphae of Candida can be seen in HPE.

Pseudomonas (Option B): Pseudomonas infections are commonly seen in immunocompromised patients and rarely cause esophagitis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of long-standing Gastroesophageal reflux disease was evaluated for persistent symptoms. Upper GI endoscopy was done and a biopsy taken. Given below is the histopathology image of the biopsy specimen. Which among the following histological changes is responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histopathology image shows metaplastic columnar epithelium (specialised) with goblet cells seen adjacent to squamous epithelium of the oesophagus, suggestive of columnar metaplasia. Hence, the patient is suspected to have Barrett's oesophagus resulting from long-standing GERD.

  • Barrett's oesophagus develops in patients with chronic GERD and represents columnar metaplasia of the oesophageal squamous mucosa.
  • Barrett's oesophagus is a risk factor for the development of adenocarcinoma.
  • Barrett’s oesophagus can be of two types:
    • Long-segment: Barrett's mucosa extends 3 cm or more.
    • Short-segment: Barrett's mucosa extends less than 3 cm

Explanation of other options:

Squamous metaplasia (Option A): The most common epithelial metaplasia is columnar to squamous; it occurs in the respiratory tract in response to chronic irritation, as in the habitual cigarette smoker. The development of squamous cell carcinoma in areas of the lungs where the normal columnar epithelium has been replaced by squamous epithelium is one example.

Columnar dysplasia (Option C): Dysplasia refers to disordered epithelial growth, characterised by cellular pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, and a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, and failure of epithelial cells to mature as they migrate to the oesophageal surface. Dysplastic glands display budding, irregular shapes, and cellular crowding. With progression, epithelial cells may invade the lamina propria, a feature that defines progression to intramucosal carcinoma.

Malignancy (Option D): Adenocarcinomas of the oesophagus can result from Barrett’s oesophagus, which will be characterised by tumours that typically produce mucin and form glands.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with a history of long-term antibiotic use presented with abdominal and watery diarrhoea. Given below are the findings from the colonoscopy of the affected region. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The mucosal surface of the colon seen here is hyperemic and is partially covered by a yellow-green exudate; this, along with a history of prolonged antibiotic use, suggests Pseudomembranous enterocolitis in this patient.

Pseudomembranous colitis:

  • Pseudomembranous colitis is generally caused by Clostridium difficile and is also referred to as antibiotic-associated colitis or antibiotic-associated diarrhoea.
  • Risk factors for difficile-associated colitis include antibiotic treatment, advanced age, hospitalisation, and immunosuppression.
  • Typically presents with watery diarrhoea due to the toxin produced by Clostridium difficile.
  • Toxins stimulate monocytes and macrophages to release IL-8, resulting in neutrophilic infiltration.
  • Gross features:
    • Cap lesions: Due to sloughing over the ulcer
    • Pseudomembrane: Formed by pus lining over the epithelium
  • Histopathology: Focal, explosive lesion appearing like an expansile mushroom or volcanic eruption.

Explanation of other options:

Crohn’s disease (Option B): Polymorphisms of NOD2, the strongest risk gene for Crohn's disease. The presence of multiple, separate, sharply delineated areas of disease, resulting in skip lesions and gives the cobblestone appearance. 

Ulcerative colitis (Option C): Ulcerative colitis predisposes to infection with C. difficile and Campylobacter jejuni. Grossly, involved colonic mucosa appears red and granular with broad-based ulcers. Isolated islands of regenerating mucosa often bulge into the lumen to create pseudopolyps, and the tips of these polyps may fuse to create mucosal bridges. Continuous ulcers cause loss of haustrations to resulting in a lead pipe appearance.

Amoebic colitis (Option D): Presents with bloody diarrhoea. Amoeba produces histolysin, which results in flask-shaped ulcers. On histopathology, trophozoites of amobae showing erythrophagocytosis can be seen.

questions.text: A gross specimen of colon from a  20-year-old male with a history of osteomas of the skull. Which among the following is the likely diagnosis based on the gross findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The gross picture shows multiple polyps with numerous small polyps covering the colonic mucosa. Given the history of skull osteomas and these gross findings, adenomatous polyposis should be suspected.

  • Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant disorder in which patients develop numerous colorectal adenomas as teenagers.
  • At least 100 polyps are necessary for a diagnosis of classic FAP, but thousands may be present.
  • It is caused by somatic mutations of the APC gene, which is a key negative regulator of the Wnt signalling pathway.
  • FAP can be associated with Gardner and Turcot syndrome.

Explanation of other options:

Crohn’s disease (Option B): Crohn's disease is a chronic transmural inflammation which presents with skip lesions and, cobblestone appearance. They are associated with strictures or fistulas, rather than diffuse polyposis. Osteomas are not associated. Extraintestinal manifestations include uveitis, migratory polyarthritis, sacroileitis, ankylosing spondylitis, erythema nodosum, cutaneous granulomas, and clubbing of the fingertips.

Ulcerative colitis (Option C): Ulcerative colitis involves continuous mucosal ulceration and is characterised by pseudopolyps and loss of haustrations resulting in a lead pipe appearance. Extraintestinal manifestations of ulcerative colitis overlap with those of Crohn's disease.

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent abdominal pain and hyperpigmentation in the buccal mucosa. On colonoscopy evaluation, polyps in the colon were identified and sent for biopsy. Given below is the histology of the biopsy specimen. What is the likely type of polyp as per histology findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical features of abdominal pain and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation, along with histology showing an arborising network of smooth muscle within the polyp, are characteristic of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. This condition is associated with hamartomatous polyps of the gastrointestinal tract.

Explanation of other options:

Inflammatory (Option B): Polyps that form as part of the solitary rectal ulcer syndrome are an example of a purely inflammatory lesion. Patients present with a clinical triad of rectal bleeding, mucus discharge, and an inflammatory lesion of the anterior rectal wall. The distinctive histologic features include mixed inflammatory infiltrates, erosion, and epithelial hyperplasia, together with prolapse-induced lamina propria fibromuscular hyperplasia.

Adenomatus  (Option C): Adenomatous polyps are neoplastic and are precursors to the majority of colorectal adenocarcinomas. Adenomas can be classified as tubular, tubulovillous, or villous based on their architecture. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant disorder in which patients develop numerous colorectal adenomas.

Hyperplastic (Option D): Colonic hyperplastic polyps are benign epithelial proliferations-tions. Histologically, hyperplastic polyps are composed of mature goblet and absorptive cells with a serrated surface architecture that is the morphologic hallmark of these lesions.
